bib_record.title: Total and differential cross sections of 10 to 95 MeV proton-induced fission of actinide nuclei

free_txt: In English.
the article is not available -SD
V.G.Khlopin Radium Institute's
proton synchrotron.
Uncertainty of the target weight.
Inhomogeneity of the layer thickness.
V.G.Khlopin Radium Institute's
proton synchrotron.
Beam energy degradation in the targets, the
detectors and the monitor foil.
Negligible: fission induced by background neutrons
Thin-film breakdown counters of fission
fragments, placed at 0,45,90,135 and 180 deg. to the
beam direction
The quoted errors include:
* the uncertainty of the target weight;
* the inhomogeneity of the layer thickness;
* the uncertainty of measuring the proton
beam current;
* the statistics of fission events in the main and
calibration measurements;
* the uncertainty estimated from the spread of data
obtained in different measurement series;
the uncertainty of measuring the proton beam
current
Two 238-U targets, about 500 mu-g/cm**2, on the
100-mu-m thick aluminum foils, were installed
back-to-back at 45 deg. to the beam axis. Between the
targets there was a 0.6-mm thick copper foil
for monitoring.
Target composition :
the targets had a small admixture of 252-Cf to provide
calibration of the detectors simultaneously to the
beam measurements
Data from the text of 91GAUSSG,214,1991
Performed: beam energy degradation in the targets
and the detectors.
Negligible: fission induced by background neutrons,
energy dependence of the angular anisotropy of
fission, the dependence of the detection efficiency
on the energy and angular distributions of fission
fragments.
-By authors-
segments of the relative fission cross section energy
dependence obtained with different initial proton
energies were sewed together with the use of the
least-square method.
The absolute fission cross sections were obtained with
the use of the absolute measurement at 62 MeV (see
subent O0606002).
Thin-film breakdown counters of fission
fragments, placed close to the targets
perpendicularly to the beam axis. Relative detector
calibration was performed in the same geometry but
without the copper filters, with the use of the
proton beam with energy of about 100 MeV.
. The quoted errors include the uncertainty of
the target weight, the inhomogeneity of the layer
thickness, the statistics of fission events in the
main and calibration measurements and the uncertainty
estimated from the spread of data obtained in
different measurement series.
The quoted errors do not include the uncertainty
of the absolute fission cross section measurement.
Absolute measurements.
The range-energy tables were
taken from: O.F.Nemets et al. Handbook on nuclear
physics. Kiev, 1975 (in Russian). A few irradiations
were done with different initial proton energies.
Total fission
cross sections are not compiled in the given entry.
In Russian.
A stack of 10 U-238 targets, each about 500 mu-gr/cm2,
was installed perpendicularly to the beam axis.
Copper filters were placed between the targets to
provide the proton beam energy degradation.
Target composition:
Data from the text of 91GAUSSG,214,1991
Performed: beam energy degradation in the targets and
the detectors, difference in angular
anisotropy of fission for the nuclides under study.
Negligible: fission induced by background neutrons.
Thin-film breakdown counters of fission
fragments, placed on both sides of the target pair in
order to detect the fragments of each nuclide
separately. The relative calibration of the detectors
was performed with the use of double-sided U-238
targets irradiated by protons with the same energy as
for the main measurements.
The quoted errors include the uncertainty of
the weight of the main and calibration targets,
the inhomogeneity of the layer thickness for the main
and calibration targets, and the statistics of fission
events in the main and calibration measurements.
Two pairs of back-to-back targets with layers
of Th-232 and U-238, about 200 mu-g/cm**2,
were installed at 45 deg. to the beam direction.
Th-232 target composition: Th-232 - 100%.
U-238 target composition:
From tabl.1 of the 91GAUSSG,214,1991

Thin-film breakdown counters of fission
fragments, placed at 0,30,60,90,90,120,150 and 180 deg.
to the beam direction.
The quoted uncertainties are obtained in
fitting the angular distributions by the least-square
method.
In Russian.
A U-238 layer of about 150-200 mu-g/cm**2 was
obtained by vacuum evaporation to an aluminium oxide
backing about 150 mu-g/cm2 thick. The target
was installed at 45 degrees to the beam axis.
The target  had a small admixture of 252-Cf to provide
calibration of the detectors simultaneously to the
beam measurements.
